document_content.title: Referral to Cardiology for Evaluation of Chest Discomfort

sections.heading: Reason for Referral
sections.content: Ms. Jane Doe is being referred to Cardiology for evaluation of intermittent chest discomfort and palpitations that have persisted over the past two months. The referral is requested to further assess for possible underlying cardiac etiology.

sections.heading: History of Present Illness
sections.content: The patient reports episodes of chest tightness occurring primarily during periods of emotional stress or moderate exertion. The discomfort is described as a dull ache, lasting several minutes, and occasionally associated with mild shortness of breath and palpitations. She denies syncope, nausea, or diaphoresis. There is no history of similar symptoms in the past. No known allergies. No family history of premature cardiac disease.

sections.heading: Assessment
sections.content: Ms. Doe is a 35-year-old female with no significant past medical history who presents with symptoms suggestive of possible angina or cardiac arrhythmia. Recent ECG in our clinic was unremarkable, and baseline laboratory investigations including lipid panel and thyroid function tests were within normal limits. Blood pressure and heart rate are stable.

sections.heading: Plan
sections.content: Referral to Cardiology for further evaluation, including consideration of exercise stress testing and ambulatory cardiac monitoring. Recommend continuation of current lifestyle modifications, including regular moderate exercise and dietary adjustments. Advise patient to monitor symptoms and seek immediate medical attention if chest pain becomes severe or is associated with syncope.
